questions.text: What is the level of proteinuria to diagnose severe preeclampsia
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 300 mg Excretion of Proteins in urine ----> more than or equal to 300 mg in 24 hours Earlier the criteria was that women with severe preeclampsia will have proteinuria more than 2 gm. This is no longer included in the criteria to say severe preeclampsia, it has been removed from the criteria. Other parameters also removed from severe preeclampsia are IUGR and oliguria. Now the criteria to say its sever is BP more than or equal to 160/110 and /or evidence of end organ damage which includes 1) pulmonary oedema 2) liver enzymes more than twice the normal value 3) serum creatinine more than 1.1 4) platelet count less than 1 lakh 5) cerebral and visual symptoms

questions.text: Drug of choice for hypertension in pregnancy
questions.solution: C Ref.: Williams Obstetrics 24/e p760,1005 Antihypertensive drugs in pregnancy The antihypertensive of choice in pregnancy is labetalol, Drug of choice for chronic hypertension in pregnancy is methyldopa Drug of choice for acute hypertension in pregnancy is iv labetalol or iv hydralazine. Both can be used as first line drugs while the single best anser is labetalol. Nifedipine can also be used as first line drug for same

questions.text: Antihypertensive not used in pregnancy
questions.solution: A Ref.: Williams obstetrics 24/e p 10005 ACE inhibitors are contraindicated in pregnancy. Other drugs that should not be used as routine antihypertensives in pregnancy are 1) ARBs 2) Beta blockers 3) Diazoxide

questions.text: Anticipated preterm delivery . Dose of dexamethasone given to mother is
questions.solution: D Ref.: WHO reproductive health library https:// apps.who. Int/rhl pregnancy _childbirth / complication / preterm _birth/cd004454_hofmeyeargi_ com/en/ Yes the dose of dexamethasone is 6mg every 12hrly for four doses. It is now the national guideline to be given if there is threat of preterm delivery to bring about fetal lung maturation. The dose of betamethasone is 12 mg i/m 2 doses 24 hrs apart

questions.text: Carbetocin dose for PPH is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Carbetocin is a long-acting synthetic analogue of oxytocin used to prevent postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) due to uterine atony following childbirth. The recommended dosage for PPH prevention is a single 100 ?g dose, administered either intravenously (IV) or intramuscularly (IM). For IV administration, the dose should be given slowly over one minute. This administration should occur as soon as possible after the delivery of the infant, preferably before the removal of the placenta. This dosing regimen is supported by various clinical guidelines and studies, highlighting its efficacy in reducing the need for additional uterotonics and minimizing blood loss.

questions.text: What are the cut off values in 2 hr oral glucose tolerance test for fasting and at 1 hours and 2 hours after meals respectively
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ref.: William obstetrics 24/e p1137 The two hour OGTT with a glucose load of 75gm as recommended by IAPDSG and ADA has the following cut offs Fasting more than or equal to 92mg/dl OR One hour value more than or equal to 180mg/dl OR Two hour value more than or equal to 153mg/dl Even if one value is deranged the we make a diagnosis of GDM

questions.text: A G6+0+0 Lady with h/o recurrent early abortions comes to you with a missed abortion at 12 weeks . Which of the following test is not warrented
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Ref.: Williams obstetrics 24/e p358 Syphilis does not cause recurrent early abortions as in syphilis the gestational age of pregnancy losses keeps increasing with every pregnancy. The most common cause among known causes of RPL is APLA and hence testing for the APLA antibodies is done in these patients, these are lupus anticoagulant and anticardiolipin antibodies. Chromosomal anomalies are responsible for 4% cases of RPL and it is an estblished cause of RPL so karyotype is important. The other causes of RPL are uterine structural anomalies and endocrinopathies.

questions.text: A mother comes with history of antenatal fetal death due to neural tube defect in first child . What is the amount folic acid you will prescribe during preconceptional counselling ( in micrograms / day)?
questions.solution: D Ref.: Williams obstetrics 24/e p1104 The dose of folic acid in high risk pregnancies like women with previous neural tube defects and women on antiepileptics has to be 4 gm/day. Hence the answer is 4000mcg Also in these high risk patients folic acid should be started as soon as the patient presents preconceptionally. Giving this dose reduces the recurrence risk by 72% The recurrence risk of NTD when one previous child is affected is 4% while when two previous children are affected the recurrence risk is 10%

questions.text: Earliest diagnosis of viable pregnancy can be established safely by
questions.solution: A Ref.: Williams obstetrics 24/e p195 Fetaal viability can be assessed with cardiac activity and the safest and ealr diagnosis of live intrauterine pregnancy is by ultrasound for cardiac activity which can be seen by 6 weeks Doppler is not completely safe and is only used in special circumstances and not as routine

questions.text: What is the approved dose of misoprostol in emergent management of postpartum hemorrhage?
questions.solution: D. 1000mcg Ref: Williams Obstetrics 24/e p 785 The approved dose of misoprostol as per WHO is 800mcg sublingually since this is not in options we will go with 1000mcg and it can be given per rectally. 600mcg is the dose for prophylaxis of PPH

questions.text: Following fetal tocographic finding was seen in a 30- year old female patient in labor. what does it suggest?
questions.solution: A Ref: Williams obstetrics 24/e p 340 These are variable decelerations seen due to cord compression. Also the baseline shows normal beat to beat variability. Hence this is normal NST tracing

questions.text: What is the best time to give anti- D to a pregnant patient?
questions.solution: b. 28 weeks Ref: Williams obstetrics 24/e p 312 A patient who is Rh negative is followed up with ICT if ict is negative even at 28 weeks then we give 300mcg anti D as prophylaxis for any possible fetomaternalhaemorrhage that could happen from aanywhere between 28-40 weeks. This anti D will be repeated after delivery if the baby is rh positive as mostly the FMH happens at delivery. 300 mcg Anti D will neutralize about 30 ml of fetal blood and 15ml of fetal RBCs

questions.text: Modified BPP consists of :
questions.solution: a. NST with AFI Ref: Williams obstetrics 24/e p 342-434 Modified BPP has only two components which are NST and AFI out of these two NST tells about acute injury to fetus while AFI tells about chronic uteroplacental insufficiency The complete BPP also called as manning score has 5 components out of which four are seen on ultrasound while one component is NST. The four ultrasound parameters are fetal breathing movement, gross body movements ,fetal tone and amniotic fluid

questions.text: In the pelvic inlet, which is the shortest anteroposterior diameter?
questions.solution: b. Obstetric conjugate Ref: Williams obstetrics 24/e p 32 The shortest AP diameter of pelvis is the obstetric conjugate which measures 10.5cm but it cannot be clinically assessed to assess this we assess the diagonal conjugate which measures 12 cm and then subtract 1.5 cm from it. To say that the pelvic inlet is contracted the diameter should be less than 10cm

choices.text: Anytime as soon as she presents to the clinic irrespective of pregnancy
As soon as pregnancy is confirmed

questions.text: A 23-year-old lady taking antiepileptics for a seizure disorder gets married. When should folic acid supplementation advised to the patient?
questions.solution: a. Anytime as soon as she presents to the clinic irrespective of pregnancy Ref: Williams obstetrics 24/e p 159 She is a high risk patient and we start on folic acid as sje as she presents preconceptionally. The dose to be given is 4gm/day

questions.text: Estrogen and progesterone in the first 2 months of pregnancy are produced by :
questions.solution: d. Corpus luteum Ref: Williams obstetrics 24/e p 169 The progesterone synthesis in the early pregnancy is done by corpus luetum which is maintained by hcg. At 8-10 weeks placenta takes over the function of corpus luteum.placenta uses maternal LDL cholesterol for the sunthesis of progesterone and fetal DHEAS for the synthesis of estrogens

questions.text: Drug of choice for pregnancy – induced hypertension is:
questions.solution: d. Alpha methyldopa Ref: Williams obstetrics 24/e, p 760, 1005 Already discussed above Drugs not used as antihypertensives in pregnancy are • ACE inhibitors • Angiotensin receptor blockers • Beta blockers • Diuretics ( used only in cardiac indications in pregnancy) • diaxozide

questions.text: All of the following increase at full term in pregnancy except:
questions.solution: d. Cardiac output Ref: Williamobstetrics24/e The cardiac output starts increasing as early as 5 weeks of gestational age and reaches peak value at 32 weeks after this there is no further increase in ncardiac output until the second stage of labour. There is no increase at term. The GFR increases in pregnancy by 50%

questions.text: Double bleb sign in USG are depictive of
questions.solution: b. Amniotic sac and yolk sac Ref: Williamsobstetrics24/epage170 The double bleb sign is a sign of early intrauterine pregnancy and it is seen as two bleb inside the gestational sac where one bleb is amniotic sac and other is yolk sac The other signs of early intrauterine pregnancy are double decidual sac sign and intradecidual sign

questions.text: An episiotomy is to be performed in a primi gravida in labor. Which of these is an advantage of mediolateral episiotomy over midline episiotomy:
questions.solution: A Lesser chance of extension Ref: Williamsobstetrics24/ePage551 The mediolateral episiotomy causes more blood loss, has higher breakdown rates and causes more dyspareunia but has lesser chances of extension as compared to midline episiotomy.

questions.text: A 22 year gravida3 para2 lady delivers a normal child followed by delivery of an intact placenta . Following delivery the lady develops .severe per vaginal bleeding after 30minutes. On table sonogram revealed retained placental tissue. what is suspected type of placenta:
questions.solution: A Placenta succenturiata Ref: Williamsobstetrics24/epage117 Placenta with accessory lobe is called as succenturiata and this accessory lobe may be left behind after the delivery of the main placenta and can present as PPH

choices.text: Terminate pregnancy because of high risk of infections
Continue pregnancy with use of antibiotic through pregnancy with use of antibiotics throughout pregnancy

questions.text: A 30 year G3P2 with 10 weeks of amenorrhea comes with an intrauterine pregnancy with intrauterine contraceptive device in situ. On pelvic examination, the string of the IUCD was visible at the cervical us. Patient wishes to continue pregnancy. What will you do:
questions.solution: B Remove intrauterine contraceptive device Ref: RCOG website consensus guidelines Pregnancy with intrauterine device in situ, if the threads are visible then the copper t should be removed while if threads are not visible then it can be left in uterus but it increases the risk of preterm labour and abortions

questions.text: A primigravida comes to the labor room at 40weeks+ 5days gestation for induction of labor. On pervaginal examination, the cervix is 1cm dilated and 30% effaced. The vertex is at -1 station and the cervix is soft and posterior. What will be the modified bishop score for this lady
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 5Ref:WilliamsObstetrics24/epage526

questions.text: The instrument shown below is used for what procedure:
questions.solution: B endometrial biopsy Ref: Shaw’sTextbookofgynecology15/e pg 246 This is a karmans cannula and is used for suction evacuation and also for endometrial biopsy in the OPD. The endometrial biopsy taken with it is also called as endometrial aspiration cytology.

questions.text: A30 year old primigravida presented at 10weeks gestation with painless bright red bleeding. Per vaginum. On examination the uterus is 12weeks size. ultrasonogram revealed the following picture. what is the likely diagnosis:
questions.solution: Hydatiform Mole Ref: Williamobstetrics24/ePage399 This is the characteristic ultrasound appearance called as snow storm appearance and this is characteristic to complete mole. Also in the ultrasound there will be absent of fetal tissue and the ovaries of the patient of complete mole may also show theca lutein cyst of ovary. A partial mole may be misdiagnosed on ultrasound and the report may come as missed abortion.

questions.text: A routine ultrasound done at 20weeks period of gestation in a 31 year old gravida 1 para 0 revealed anomaly. The second opinion. What congenital anomaly would you explain to the couple:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Anencephaly Ref: Williamsobstetrics24/epage201 The characteristic ultrasound finding of anencephaly is called as frog eye sign or mickey mouse sign. Ultrasound is best screening test for neural tube defects. Anencephaly m ay be earliest picked up on ultrasound by 10 weeks but the ideal time to see this is 14 weeks. Level 2 ultrasound is the anomaly scan and is done between 18-20 weeks.

choices.text: Each small square represents one hour
Alert and action lines are separated by a difference of 4 hours
Partogeraph recording should be started at a cervical dilation of 4 cm
Send the patient to first referral unit if the labor progression line crosses the alert line

questions.text: Patrograph represents various stages of labor with respect to time. True about partograph is all except:
questions.solution: a. Each small square represents one hour Ref: Williams 24/epg 452 Each large square in partogram is equivalent to 1 hour All other statements are correct. Plotting on partogram begins at 4 cm which is the WHO definition of active phase. Latent phase of labour is not plotted on the modified WHO partogram

choices.text: Secondary arrest after progression of labor
Prolonged latent phase/primary arrest of labor

questions.text: The following graph represents the stages of labor. Which of the following statements is true about the graph C?
questions.solution: a. Secondary arrest after progression of labor Graph a IS PROLONGED latent phase Graph B is prolonged active phase or dystocia of labour Graph C is arrest of dilatation.

questions.text: What is done for screening of Down’s syndrome in first trimester?
questions.solution: a. Beta HCG and PAPP-A Ref: Willaams 24/e pg 289 The first trimester test is called as dual test and it includes serum HCG and serum PAPPA. In a positive test the HCG levels are more than expected and PAPPA is less than expected. The dual test is done between 11-13 weeks . The second trimester test are triple test and quadruple test than can be done between 15-22 weeks. Triple test includes serum assessment of 3 markers that are HCG, AFP and UNCONJUGATED ESTRIOL. The quadruple test includes the markers of triple test plus inhibin A.

questions.text: What dose of misoprostol is used orally to control bleeding in post partum hemorrhages?
questions.solution: C 800micrograms Ref: WillaimsObsterics 24/e p 785: https:// www.who.in/ bulletin/volumes/87/9/08-055715/en/ The dose of misoprostol for treatment of PPH is 800 and the route is sublingual while the dose for prophylaxis is 600 mcg oral. Misoprostol is not the drug of choice for PPH. The drug of choice for both prophylaxis and treatment is oxytocin.

questions.text: What is the maximum capacity of bakri balloon which is used in postpartum haemorrhage?
questions.solution: c. 500 mL. Ref: Williams 24/e pg 786 Once the patient is not responding to medical management then the next step in the management is balloon tamponade. We may use bakri balloon or Sengstaken- Blakemore tube and the maximum amount for distension of these is 500ml for this purpose. Once this is also not working then the next step is surgical management.

choices.text: Observe the patient and wait for increase in uterine contractions
Sedate the patient by and give Phenergan to decease labor pains
Induce labor by artificial rupture of membranes

questions.text: A 38 week primigravida presented to the labor room with minimal labor pains and contraction. On examination, the cervix is 2 cm dilated and 50% effaced. The heart rate of the patient is 86/min and blood pressure is 126/76 mm Hg. What should be done next?
questions.solution: B. Observe the patient and wait for increase in uterine contractions Patient is in latent phase of labour and she has minimal pail. We just need to wait and watch fro progress of labour Managenment for patients who are not tolrating latent phase is therapeutic rest, if paient is well rested or whow has alraedy received therapeutic rest oxytocin augmentation can be done Epidural analgesia with oxytocin can be given to patients who need pain relief and there is prolonged latent phase

choices.text: Can only be done upto 72 days
Ultrasound should be done in all cases
Only a person certified under MTP act can perform medical termination of pregnancy
If the patient has an IUCD in –situ, it doesen’t need to be removed

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding medical abortion?
questions.solution: c. Only a person certified under MTP act can performs medical termination of pregnancy Ref: Shaw 158/e pg 2447-245, Williamspg 368 Medical outpatient abortion is allowed as per the MTP act up to 7 weeks AND ultrasound is not mandatory either before or after the procedure. IUD with pregnancy and if the thread is seen then the IUD must be removed .

choices.text: Give another dose of Anti D 72 hour postpartum depending on the baby blood group
Give another dose of Anti D 72 hour postpartum irrespective of baby blood group
No need additional dose since she is ICT negative

questions.text: Rh-negative mother, ICT negative was given Anti D during 28 weeks of pregnancy. Which of the following is the ideal one?
questions.solution: (a) Give another dose of Anti D 72 hour postpartum depending on the baby blood group Ref. RCOG guidelines All Rh negative mothers who have Rh positive babies should be given Anti D after delivery. It has to be a full dose of 300mcg and the ideal time to give it is within 72 hrs of delivery. Rh negative pregnant patients whose ICT is negative are also given prophylactic anti D AT 28 weeks which is again a full dose of 300mcg.

choices.text: Give warm compress to the perineum
Manual support to perineum with deflexion of head

questions.text: Which of the following is a WHO guideline is second stage of labour?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Give warm compress to the perineum Ref. WHO guidelines Routine episiotomy is not to be given for prevention of perineal tears. Manual support is given to the perineum but the head has to be maintained in flexion.lithotomy position is not mandatory. As per the NICE guidelines warm perineal compresses are shown to reduce perineal tears.

questions.text: Twin peak sign is seen in
questions.solution: A • Twin peak sign is also known as lambda sign seen between 10 to 14 weeks. Best time to look for it is 10 weeks. • T sign is seen in monochorionic twins

questions.text: A gravida women with 42 days of amenorrhea and spotting per vaginum presented to OPD. What is the next step to diagnose her condition?
questions.solution: B Any reproductive woman presenting with amennorea, the first test done must be urine pregnancy test. All the tests for HCG looks out for the ? subunit of HCG. • Urine pregnancy test has a sensitivity of about 20IU/L • Serum pregnancy test has a sensitivity of 1 IU/L

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with acute fatty liver of pregnancy
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Deficiency of maternal LCHAD cute fatty liver during pregnancy (AFLP) is an emergency and potentially fatal condition occurring during the peripartum period. It is characterized by fatty microvascular infiltration of hepatocytes and has an incidence rate of approximately one in 7,000 to one in 20,000 pregnancies. It may induce profound liver failure and can be accompanied by renal failure, polydipsia/polyuria, disseminated intravascular coagulation, hypoglycemia, and encephalopathy. Emergency delivery at the appropriate time is crucial to control the development of AFLP.

questions.text: Cordocentesis done in
questions.solution: C Most common time to do the tests are • Chorionic villous sampling = 11 to 13 weeks • Amniocentesis= 16 to 18 weeks • Chordocentesis = 18 to 20 weeks

questions.text: Spielberg’s criteria is used in the diagnosis of
questions.solution: A Criterias used for various ectopic pregnancies are • Spigelberg criteria: primary ovarian pregnancy • Studiford criteria: abdominal pregnancy • Palmans criteria: Cervical pregnancy

choices.text: Maternal uric acid, urine estriol, PA

questions.text: Bart test will include testing for
questions.solution: Ans: Bart test is the other name for triple test or kottering test.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for the below placenta
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Placenta Marginata: In this condition, the edge of the placenta is only slightly raised because the fetal membranes insert close to the edge of the chorionic plate. It looks like a thin, flat ring around the placenta. This is usually a benign and incidental finding, with no impact on the pregnancy or fetal growth. Placenta Circumvallata: Here, the fetal membranes fold back over the edge of the placenta, forming a thick, prominent white ring. The chorionic plate is significantly smaller than the basal plate. This can sometimes lead to complications, such as vaginal bleeding, preterm labor, placental abruption, or restricted fetal growth.

choices.text: 14 days before end of existing cycle
14 days after beginning of next cycle

questions.text: What is the ideal time to conceive.?
questions.solution: A Luteal phase is constant ie 14 days. So 14 days before the end of existing cycle is the day on which she will be ovulating.

questions.text: Manoeuvres performed in shoulder dystocia include? (PGI TYPE)
questions.solution: A,B,E Explanation: Maneuvers useful in shoulder dystocia include

choices.text: Congenital anomaly scan at 20 to 22 weeks

questions.text: Complete antenatal screening for aneuploidy include(s) all except? (PGI TYPE)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D And E) Explanation: Antenatal screen for aneuploidy includes

choices.text: More in those who are exposed to trophoblastic villi for the first time
More in twins due to higher trophoblastic villi
Magnesium sulphate is highly effective in most patients of pre-eclampsia

questions.text: True regarding risk of pre-eclampsia? (PGI TYPE)
questions.solution: A,B,C,D,E Explanation: All options are correct.

questions.text: Which among the following can be done for gestational dating? (PGI TYPE)
questions.solution: C,D,E Explanation: Crown rump length (CRL) is best done between 7 to 10 weeks and can be done upto 12 weeks. Thereafter, BPD should be used to assess gestational age, between 12 to 26 weeks.

questions.text: Not a part of active management of third stage of labour? (PGI TYPE)
questions.solution: A,B,D Explanation: Steps in active management of 3rd stage of labour include

choices.text: Young female with Turner-like phenotypic features
Repeated spontaneous abortions in a couple

questions.text: Karyotyping need not be done in which patient profile(s)? (PGI TYPE)
questions.solution: B Explanation: Presence of seizures alone is not an indication for karyotyping

choices.text: Marfan syndrome with dilated aortic root of 5 cm

questions.text: Contraindications of pregnancy include? (PGI TYPE)
questions.solution: B, C,E Explanation: Heart diseases where pregnancy is CI Marfan syndrome with dilated aortic root >45 mm Coarctation of aorta Eisenmenger syndrome/Severe pulmonary hypertension NYHA class 3 and 4 LV ejection fraction <30% Severe fixed lesion like severe MS, AS etc

questions.text: Indications for VBAC may include? (PGI TYPE)
questions.solution: B,D Explanation: Vaginal birth after caesarean (VBAC) is performed in previous LSCS (1 or more) but no CPD or contracted pelvis. Presence of previous classic CS or CPD or malpresentation in present pregnancy are contraindications for VBAC

questions.text: High risk of preterm labour exists with cervical length less then ? (PGI TYPE)
questions.solution: B Cervical length is best assessed in 2nd trimester between 18 to 2o weeks Most important risk factor of preterm labour is previous history of preterm labour. If this history is present , the we start assessment at around 14 weeks If cervical length is < 2.5 cm and there is no history of preterm labour, we put her on micronized progesterone If cervical length is <2.5cm and there is history of preterm labour, then we will do prophylactic cervical circlage

questions.text: Sonographic finding to confirm pregnancy include(s)? (PGI TYPE)
questions.solution: A, C, D True sac eccentric in position, symmetrical and shows double decidual sac sign Gestational sac can be visualised on TVS by 4week+3days and on TAS by 5 weeks Yolk sac appears on TVS by 5.5 week and on TAS by 5.5 to 6 weeks

questions.text: In a baby, all of the following can be seen due to maternal uncontrolled diabetes, except? (PGI TYPE)
questions.solution: A, D Maternal diabetes increases the risk of gross congenital anomalies ( not chromosomal anomalies) It can lead to macrosomia, open neural tube defects and intrauterine death Target blood glucose levels for a woman with diabetes in pregnancy are FBS <95 I hr PPBS <140 2 hr PPBS < 120 Average CBG 100 HbA1c < 6%

choices.text: Fetus should be in mid-saggital plane
Neck of fetus/baby should be extended
Callipers should be applied at the outer border of nuchal space

questions.text: Pre-requisites for identifying and approaching nuchal translucency is/are? (PGI TYPE)
questions.solution: A,B,E Neck of fetus must be in neutral position Callipers should be applied at the inner to inner border of nuchal space Head, neck and thorax region should be magnified to look for nuchal translucency Widest area is measured. Multiple measurements are taken and their average is considered ≥3mm is considered positive screening test.

questions.text: Quadruple test done at?
questions.solution: B The second trimester test are triple test and quadruple test than can be done between 15-22 weeks. Triple test includes serum assessment of 3 markers that are HCG, AFP and UNCONJUGATED ESTRIOL. The quadruple test includes the markers of triple test plus inhibin A.

questions.text: Fimbriectomy is associated with-
questions.solution: D

questions.text: In a pregnant women which of the following alters?
questions.solution: D This is because of increase in beta HCG whose alpha subunit resembles that of TSH. This stimulates thyroid gland to produce more T3

choices.text: Rapid flexion of thigh on abdomen
Pushing the one shoulder of fetus

questions.text: In shoulders dystocia procedure done is-
questions.solution: A First procedure done in shoulder dystocia is rapid flexion of thigh on abdomen and abduction. This is known as MC Robert’s maneuver. Last maneuver done is zavanelli. Fundal pressure is absolutely contraindicated in shoulder dystocia.

questions.text: Which of the following drug is used for lung maturity-
questions.solution: A Dexamethasone Dose: 6mg Intramuscular 4 doses gven 12 hrs apart

questions.text: Drug not used in HTN in pregnancy?
questions.solution: A Drugs not used as antihypertensives in pregnancy are ACE inhibitors Angiotensin receptor blockers Beta blockers Diuretics ( used only in cardiac indications in pregnancy) diaxozide

choices.text: Start ART in second trimester and continue life long
Start ART immediately and continue life long
Start ART immediately and stop after delivery
Start ART in second trimester and continue till 6 months of delivery

questions.text: A woman was found to be HIV positive in first trimester and when should ART to be started?
questions.solution: B ART must be started as soon as HIV is dioagnosed and treatment has to be continued for life long Regime recommended is TLE Goal is to keep viral load <1000 copies/ml

questions.text: Peripartum cardiomyopathy is most commonly seen at?
questions.solution: D Peripartum cardiomyopathy is cardiac disease developing after 36 wks of pregnancy till 5 months post partum. Acute heart failure with ejection fraction <45%.

choices.text: History of Manual removal of placenta

questions.text: Which of the following is not a high risk for antenatal care?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Infertility considered as high risk due to complications like GDM, pre eclampsia, antepartum hemorrhage, pre term labour,low birth weight Anemia and obesity are included under high risk pregnancy

questions.text: All of the following are causes of secondary PPH except?
questions.solution: D Anemia results in early PPH. Retained placental tissue is most common cause of secondary PPH (beyond 24 hrs to 12 weeks post partum)

choices.text: Can be done before 6 weeks of POG
Detects fetal DNA in maternal blood
It’s a confirmatory test for downs
It is done only in congenital malformation suspicion

questions.text: Which of the following is true about NIPT?
questions.solution: B NIPT- non invasive prenatal test Used as screening test for down’s syndrome Test will detect cell free DNA in maternal blood Test done beyond 10 weeks of pregnancy Always confirmed by invasive test following NIPT

questions.text: ART (assisted reproductive technique) predisposes to-
questions.solution: B In general most common type of twins are di-zygotic twins. And most common type of twins is DCDA

questions.text: In ART, cells from zygote are taken and which test is done?
questions.solution: A Tests done are Single nucleotide polymorphism ( single gene mutation) Karyo-mapping Genomic hybridization PCR/FISH

questions.text: What should be couple protection rate if NRR 1 to be achieved-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The target of NRR is 1. It gives replacement level & Population stabilization. To attain NRR =1 , we need TFR= <2.1 To attain TFR=2.1 we need a couple protection rate of 60%

questions.text: Anaesthesia of choice for pre-eclampsa patient is-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Spinal anesthesia is now widely regarded as a safe and effective option for cesarean delivery in patients with severe preeclampsia, provided there are no contraindications such as coagulopathy or thrombocytopenia. Recent studies have demonstrated that while spinal anesthesia may cause hypotension, this is typically less frequent and less severe in preeclamptic patients compared to healthy parturients. Moreover, any hypotension that does occur is usually short-lived and easily managed with vasopressors like ephedrine . A. General anesthesia (GA) is incorrect because it is associated with increased risks in preeclamptic patients, including difficult airway management, aspiration, and hypertensive responses during intubation. GA is generally reserved for situations where neuraxial anesthesia is contraindicated or in emergencies. C. Epidural anesthesia is incorrect in this context because, although it offers gradual onset and hemodynamic stability, it has a slower onset compared to spinal anesthesia. In urgent situations requiring rapid anesthesia, spinal anesthesia is preferred due to its quick onset and reliability. D. Combined spinal-epidural (CSE) is incorrect because, while it combines the benefits of both techniques, it may not offer significant advantages over spinal anesthesia alone in the context of preeclampsia. Additionally, CSE may introduce complexities without substantial benefit in this specific scenario. Therefore, spinal anesthesia is currently considered the preferred anesthetic technique for cesarean delivery in patients with severe preeclampsia, balancing efficacy and safety.

questions.text: In which of the following cases, curettage is not done?
questions.solution: A PID It is a clinical diagnosis. Symptom is lower abdominal pain Most common complication is infertility Gold standard investigation is diagnostic laparotomy Other investigations : USG and endometrial biopsy Most common organism : chlamydia>gonorrhoea

questions.text: At what week of pregnancy can usg be done to correctly diagnose twin pregnancy?
questions.solution: A For chorionicity scan should be done beyond weeks Lambda sign/ twin peak sign seen in 10 to 14 weeks. It is a sign of dichorionic twins

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common reason to use HRT?
questions.solution: A The only reason to start HRT is hot flushes Vaginal atrophy is given lubricants followed by local administration of estrogen creams

choices.text: Per vaginal examination of uterine size corresponding to 6 weeks gestation
Ultrasounds visualization of fetal cardiac activity
Doppler assessment of fetal cardiac activity

questions.text: The most accurate and safe method to diagnose viable pregnancy at 6 weeks of gestation at 6 weeks of gestation is-
questions.solution: C Pregnancy can be diagnosed on transvaginal ultrasound as early as 5 to 6 weeks. Transabdominal ultrasoung by 6 to 7 weeks.

questions.text: Which vaccine is contraindicated in pregnancy?
questions.solution: A All live attenuated vaccines are contraindicated in pregnancy except rabies It can be given during dog bite If the woman has varicella exposure, she will be given varicella immunoglobulins

questions.text: Presenting diameter of full flexed head is
questions.solution: : A Presenting diameters Sub-occipito bregmatic – full flexion Sub-occipito frontal- deflexed head Occipito-frontal – deflexed head Occipito-posterior is a malposition

questions.text: What is the dose of ulipristal acetate?
questions.solution: B ULIPRISTAL ACETATE Emergency contraceptive Dose: 30mg Given once, can be given upto 5 days of intercourse Most effective hormonal emergency contraceptive

questions.text: Major contribution of amniotic fluid after 20 weeks of gestation is
questions.solution: B First 12 weeks: ultrafiltrate of maternal plasma 12 to 20 weeks: transudate across fetal skin Beyond 20 weeks: fetal urine

questions.text: Nuchal translucency can be detected at which week of gestation?
questions.solution: a NT measured at 11 to 13 weeks >/= 3mm is considered positive test Most commonly associated with down’s syndrome> monosomy X

questions.text: First line of treatment of mastitis in lactating mother is?
questions.solution: A Most common cause of lactional mastitis is MRSA Recommended antibiotic is cloxacillin > cephalexin

questions.text: Patient with recurrent abortion diagnosed to have anti phospholipid antibody syndrome. What will be the treatment?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) APLA More than or equal to 3 abortions at less than 10 weeks More than or equal to 1 pregnancy loss beyond 10 weeks of a morphologically normal fetus DOC in non-pregnant individuals : warfarin

questions.text: Identify the type of placenta previa shown below
questions.solution: Ans: B

questions.text: Maximum dose of PGF2 alpha used in PPH is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The drug name is carboprost( dinoprost or hemabate) Most potent drug for PPH is PGF2 alpha DOC for PPH is oxytocin

questions.text: The weight of baby at 34 weeks of gestation is 3kgs. The child shown with the features shown in the image are associated with?
questions.solution: B Macrosomia • EBW more than 4 kg • Causes / risk factors are a. Maternal diabetes b. Previous history of macrosomia c. Multiparity d. Male sex e. Post term pregnancy f. Excessive weight gain during pregnancy

questions.text: All of the following are physiological changes in pregnancy except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Physiological changes in pregnancy Increased residual volume Cardiac output increases. Maximum is immediate post partum period. Increased total protein. Serum concentration of protein decreases due to volume expansion. Reduced plasma osmolality. GFR increases by 50%. Serum creatinine value decreases.

questions.text: Overt diabetes is defined as random blood glucose more than?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Overt/ pre-gestational diabetes • Random blood glucose > 200 • Fasting > 126 • HbA1c > / = 6.5

questions.text: MgSO4 has no role in prevention of?
questions.solution: Correct answer (D) MgSO4 used to treat Impending eclampsia Recurrent seizures in eclampsia Neural protection: prevents cerebral palsy A course of antenatal corticosteroid therapy (ACS) administered to patients at risk for preterm birth reduced the incidence and severity of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) and mortality in their offspring [1]. Subsequent trials have shown that ACS also improves circulatory stability in preterm neonates, resulting in lower rates of intraventricular hemorrhage and necrotizing enterocolitis compared with unexposed preterm neonates

choices.text: Common if female fetus is preset
Associated with decreased serum uric acid levels

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about acute fatty liver of pregnancy?
questions.solution: B ACUTE FATTY LIVER OF PREGNANCY Rare disease Classically associated with malke fetus Other risk factors are: pre eclampsia, twin pregnancy Acute fatty liver can lead to hepato-renal syndromes and can cause increased serum creatinine, urea and uric acid levels It is the most common cause of acute liver failure in pregnancy It is caused due to deficiency of LCHAD enzyme

questions.text: Female with 41 week gestation confirmed by radiological assessment is very sure of her LMP. She has no uterine contractions, no effacement and no dialatation. All the following can be done except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) PGE1 tablet – misoprost can be used for cervical ripening and induction of labour PGE2 gel- dinoprostone used for cervical ripening and induction of labour Intracervical foley’s catheter and luminaria tents are mechanical methods of cervical ripening
